abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fourth Livestock
            Development Project for Ethiopia were as follows: Bank
            performance was satisfactory; and Borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: transfer of
            appropriate technology to local professionals and easy
            replicability of programs, such as the forage development
            and disease investigation components, are important
            ingredients for sustainability. To ensure an efficient
            sustainable animal health service, the private sector should
            have responsibility for importing and distributing
            veterinary drugs and medicines, and clinical field services
            should be privatized. Production of forage seed and the
            development of forage technology at the farm level are
            crucial to the development of smallholders' livestock
            farming. Continuity of senior staff in program formulation
            and implementation is highly associated with successful
            results. Considerable time and resources can be saved if
            dubious components such as the foot and mouth disease (FMD)
            and rabies vaccine production, are excluded from the outset.
            Project design should include specific provisions for all
            the activities that are necessary for the successful
            implementation of components that is taking for granted that
            molasses-urea blocks would be produced hindered the animal
            fattening component.
